DOC.HEAD: Bush Nominee For Weapons Post Draws Mixed Reviews
Eds: SUBS penultimate graf to CORRECT Greenspun's first name to Julian sted Julius
DOC.TEXT: President Bush's nominee to head nuclear weapons production said Tuesday that delays in a Senate confirmation vote are undermining national security by prolonging a leadership vacuum in the arms program. ``It is our country that is suffering'' as a result of Senate inaction, Victor Stello Jr., told the Armed Services Committee at the close of a five-hour hearing. It was the second time in five weeks that Stello had testified to the panel. ``The defense nuclear facilities are in a state of disarray,'' Stello said, alluding to a series of safety and management crises at the weapons production plants that have forced many of the key facilities to close in recent years. Bush submitted Stello's nomination to the Senate on July 24 but the first confirmation hearing was not held mid-November, when Energy Secretary James D. Watkins personally pleaded with the committee to approve the nomination quickly. Watkins said he needed Stello to improve safety conditions at the arms plants. The department has been without a confirmed head of weapons production for more than a year. The committee Tuesday heard sharply conflicting testimony about Stello's qualifications for the job and about controversial actions he took during his more than two decades as a staff official of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission, which establishes and enforces rules on the commercial use of nuclear power. Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., acting chairman of the committee, said the panel probably would meet in closed session shortly after Congress reconvenes in January to decide when to vote on recommending either confirmation or rejection of the nominee. Fewer than half of the 20-member committee attended Tuesday's hearing. Most panel members have not said publicly whether they will vote for Stello, although at least three Democratic members _ Timothy Wirth of Colorado, John Glenn of Ohio and Edward Kennedy of Massachusetts _ are strongly opposed, and all nine Republican members are expected to support the nomination. Of the five former members of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission who testified, three strongly endorsed Stello's nomination and two raised serious doubts about his suitability. John Ahearne, who was a commission member from 1978-83, said the Energy Department ``needs somebody who is tough'' enough to force a turnaround in the management of the nuclear weapons facilities, and that Stello would fit the bill. ``Vic Stello is the first name that would come to my mind'' as a good candidate for the job of assistant energy secretary for defense programs, Ahearne said. Peter Bradford, a commission member from 1977-82, said he was troubled by several allegations that have been made against Stello since the time Bradford left the agency, including a charge that Stello authorized an unusual cash payment to an informant in order to pursue a personal vendetta within the commission. Bradford said this and other allegations must be ``credibly disposed of'' by the Senate before any confirmation vote is taken. Sen. Albert Gore Jr., D-Tenn., questioned a panel of former NRC investigators about Stello's role in the investigations of the 1979 Three Mile Island nuclear power plant accident in Pennsylvania, the worst nuclear accident in U.S. history. John Sinclair, a former NRC investigator and now a member of the Commerce Department inspector general's office, said under questioning from Gore that Stello had misled Justice Department investigators about the existence of cooling pipe test records held by the utility that operated the Three Mile Island reactors. ``That makes me think Mr. Stello was more interested in making sure the company wasn't subject to any punishment ... than in protecting the public safety,'' Gore said. ``I'm deeply troubled by this testimony.'' Sinclair and two other former NRC investigators, Jim McCarten and David Gamble, plus Julian Greenspun, a former Justice Department investigator, said in response to a question from Exon that they would not recommend Stello's confirmation. In seeking to defend his actions following the Three Mile Island accident, Stello tried to read from an FBI report, but Exon stopped him, saying the report's contents could not be made public until the FBI agreed. Exon said the panel would seek to get that approval.
